keyTakeAways: Los Angeles County District Attorney George Gascón has recommended that a judge resentence Lyle and Erik Menendez, who were convicted in 1996 of murdering their parents, Jose and Kitty Menendez, in 1989.

The recommendation comes after new evidence — including a sworn statement from Roy Rosselló and a letter from Erik Menendez — was presented in 2023, alleging years of physical and sexual abuse by their father, which the defense claims may have influenced the brothers' actions.

Under California law, the brothers would be eligible for youthful parole due to their age at the time of the crimes (under 26), allowing for a sentence of life with the possibility of release after 50 years, or earlier if deemed rehabilitated.

Gascón, who is campaigning for reelection on a platform of sentencing reform, stated that today's judicial standards consider psychological abuse more seriously than in the 1990s, leading to a reevaluation of the original conviction.

The decision follows a habeas corpus petition filed by the brothers’ attorneys in 2023 and is supported by public figures like Kim Kardashian, who praised the move as correcting a 'significant wrong'.
The case has gained renewed public attention due to the Netflix series 'Monsters: The Lyle and Erik Menendez Story' and a documentary featuring the brothers discussing their trauma.
Gascón emphasized that the brothers have been model prisoners, contributing to rehabilitation efforts and self-improvement, and that they have served enough time and are now eligible for parole.

The case is significant for its implications in criminal justice reform, especially regarding how abuse and trauma are considered in sentencing decisions, and whether the legal system can reassess long-standing convictions based on new evidence and evolving norms.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Los Angeles County District Attorney George Gascón has recommended that a judge resentence Lyle and Erik Menendez, who were convicted in 1996 of murdering their parents, Jose and Kitty Menendez, in 1989. The recommendation follows a 2023 habeas corpus petition that cited new evidence, including a sworn statement from former Menudo member Roy Rosselló and a letter from Erik Menendez, alleging years of sexual and physical abuse by their father. Gascón, who supports sentencing reform and has emphasized evolving societal views on abuse, stated that the brothers have rehabilitated, have served enough time, and are eligible for parole due to their youth at the time of the crimes. The brothers’ attorneys argue that the original conviction does not fully reflect the trauma they endured, and the case has gained renewed attention due to a Netflix series and documentary. The Los Angeles Superior Court will ultimately decide on the resentencing, with a hearing expected in 30 to 45 days. The decision is significant not only for the Menendez brothers but as a broader statement on how legal systems may reassess long-standing convictions in light of new evidence and changing understandings of trauma and abuse.
title: Los Angeles District Attorney Recommends Resentencing in Decades-Old Menendez Brothers Murder Case
